prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Distinguishing Knowledge and Skills from Confidential Information

para.paratext: An employer will want to clarify the difference between the general skills learned by an employee during the course of employment and the confidential information of the employer. Employers should attempt to ensure that “unique” information to which the employee is privy is brought to the attention of the employee at the time he or she is given access to it.[1]

Generally, all parties are required to use information in a manner consistent with the circumstances in which it was provided. This duty results from the fact that the employer normally imparts information to the employee for a specific job-related purpose. The permitted use may therefore be defined in part by reference to the employee's actual duties.[2] Accordingly, where available or easily produced, an updated job description should be maintained in the employee's personnel file for use as evidence.

The courts may shift the boundary between confidential information and the employee's skills and knowledge where the information in question was produced by the employee. The courts have held in some circumstances that such information should be considered part of the employee's own working knowledge and skill. When the information is brought into being because of the initiative of the employee (in its creation, innovation or development), it may be that no duty of confidence arises since the employee may have an interest at least equal to that of the employer. In the alternative, such information may be considered to have become an intimate part of the employee's general skill and experience.[3]

See, for example, Herbert Morris Ltd. v. Saxelby, [1916] 1 A.C. 688 (H.L.); Morison v. Moat (1851), 9 Hare. 241, 68 E.R. 492 (Ch.); Triplex Safety Glass Co. v. Scorah, [1937] 4 All E.R. 693 (Ch.); United Indigo Chemical Co. v. Robinson (1931), 49 R.P.C. 178 (Ch.).
See, for example, Cercast Inc. v. Shellcast Foundries Inc. (1972), 8 C.P.R. (2d) 254 (F.C.T.D.).

Delrina Corp. v. Triolet Systems Inc. (1993), 9 B.L.R. (2d) 140, 47 C.P.R. (3d) 1 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)), at p. 169, affd 156 O.A.C. 166, 58 O.R. (3d) 339 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 21 C.P.R. (4th) vi.
